34.03.text:
I'm your host Ernabel
Demillo. In this episode

36.74.text:
we take a look at what's
making headlines in politics,

39.27.text:
arts and entertainment
and the talk of the town

42.74.text:
right here at the Solomon
R. Guggenheim Museum is

46.01.text:
“Tales of Our Time”, a
groundbreaking exhibit.

48.78.text:
I’m going to give
you a behind the scenes

50.52.text:
tour but first here's what's
ahead on our show.

55.26.text:
Inside politics, Paul Lin
reports on the Trump of

58.36.text:
the east, Philippines
president Rodrigo Duterte.

60.59.text:
Raising faith, Kyung Yoon
looks at the changing face

65.00.text:
of Christianity. Minnie
Roh shares how a modern

68.70.text:
day Korean Jane Eyre is
taking Hollywood by storm.

73.11.text:
And I discover a whole new
world with the cast of Aladdin.

77.21.text:
This and more on
Asian American Life.

81.72.text:
“Tales of Our Time”
features the works of

83.85.text:
eight young contemporary
Chinese artists who use

86.45.text:
storytelling to explore
time and space.

89.46.text:
We got a guided tour from the
curator herself.

99.20.text:
>>>XIAOYU WENG: The underlying
theme of “Tales of Our Time”

101.27.text:
is to challenge conventional
and traditional understanding

104.20.text: of how we define a place.

106.57.text:
This place can be as specific
as a city, as a location or

111.41.text:
as broad as the concept
of China. And that work is

114.88.text:
called “Mythological
Time” by Beijing based artists

118.85.text:
Sun Xun. He took his
hometown Fuxin as the starting

123.06.text:
point for his research and the
city used to host one of the

127.43.text:
biggest open coal mine in Asia
and then was the decline

132.57.text:
of the coal production the city
also went into sort of a very

136.34.text:
defunct situation. So Sun
Xun really used that

139.21.text:
metaphor to look at the
moving of powers based on

142.11.text:
the natural source of you
know energy.

149.18.text:
The robot piece is called “Can’t
Help Myself” and it's a

152.32.text:
metaphor in understanding
the border and territory

156.59.text:
controls and also the
conflicts that we're

158.53.text:
having right now. I do
feel it’s to open up their

162.86.text:
perspective and challenge
their understanding of art

166.03.text:
from China and really make
them feel like oh wow this

168.80.text:
is something that I can
only see here at the

171.17.text:
Guggenheim and also really
give me new ideas of what

175.28.text:
these artists are thinking
and what kind of works

177.74.text:
that I might expect from
them.

186.62.text:
>>>ERNABEL DEMILLO: You
can learn more about the

187.95.text:
Guggenheim's tale of our
times and all our stories

190.29.text:
by following us on Facebook at
Asian-American Life.

193.73.text:
Now up next we take
a look at the impact of

196.10.text:
Philippine politics right
here at home.

200.90.text:
>>>PAUL LIN: I'm Paul Lin.
When Donald Trump won the

203.07.text:
U.S. presidential election
one of the world leaders

205.84.text:
who quickly congratulated
him was Philippine

208.74.text:
president Rodrigo Duterte.
His brash talk has earned

212.21.text:
him the nickname Trump of
the East and both men have

215.82.text:
written a populist wave
into power.

219.35.text:
>>>LUIS FRANCIA: Similar
to Trump people feel  he says

222.59.text:
what he thinks. Unlike
traditional politicians

226.66.text:
who always hide behind
empty, what people feel is

230.76.text:
empty rhetoric, you know
they never get the sense

233.77.text:
that the politicians are
straight talkers whereas

237.30.text:
Duterte came across as a
fresh voice.

241.37.text:
>>>PAUL LIN: And one
that's not afraid to

242.74.text:
ruffle some feathers when
irritated. Whether it's

245.11.text:
the U.N. Secretary General
over human rights issues

248.48.text:
or the president of the
United States or even the

251.65.text:
Pope for causing a traffic
jam in Manila. Should the

255.46.text:
world take all this at
face value?

258.19.text:
>>>CRISTINA PASTOR: His
cabinet officials and some

259.96.text:
of his off advisers are
telling us journalists

267.97.text:
that don't take him too
seriously when he curses,

271.44.text:
when he says these words,
sometimes he doesn't

274.27.text:
really mean them.
Sometimes he says them

276.41.text:
because it's just an
expression to him because

279.41.text:
he's the kind of person
who is prone to cursing

285.05.text:
>>>PAUL LIN: Duterte’s
tough guy reputation comes

287.15.text:
from his early years as
the anti-crime mayor of

289.92.text:
Davao City. Luis Francia
recalls his first time

295.53.text:
>>>LUIS FRANCIA: He comes
roaring in on a motorcycle,

298.63.text:
45 caliber tucked into
his belt. He was young,

303.04.text:
so was I, and roguish. If
you didn't know him or

307.94.text:
his record it was very
appealing, he was

310.81.text:
overflowing with
confidence. He said yeah

313.41.text:
I can take care of this
town.

318.75.text:
>>>RODRIGO DUTERTE: I've served
government for almost 30 years.

321.69.text:
>>>PAUL LIN: Waging an iron
fisted war

323.22.text:
on criminals in which he
said the best solution is

325.66.text:
to kill them all. Organizations
from the U.N. to Amnesty

330.10.text:
International and Human
Rights Watch suggests that

333.47.text:
death squads working with
police helped execute at

336.44.text:
least 1,400 people during
his time as mayor with many

340.07.text:
thousands more killed since
he became president.

343.34.text:
>>>LUIS FRANCIA: You had
death squads operating but

346.68.text:
he's always denied that he
had a direct hand in these

351.22.text:
but you know you set the
tone, you encourage and he never

356.46.text:
went after the vigilantes.
He did bring the crime

360.76.text:
rate down so you know but the
question is at what cost.

367.17.text:
>>>PAUL LIN: It's the same
question being asked in

368.80.text:
the Philippines how can
the method be separated

371.84.text:
from the results and what
happens to civil liberties

375.14.text:
and due process in a
street justice environment.

378.58.text:
>>>LUIS FRANCIA: The dead
cannot defend themselves.

380.95.text:
So if I were to shoot you
I'll put the, which they

385.75.text:
do put the cardboard sign
drug pusher. Who's to say

390.79.text:
otherwise. Right. And most
of them have been poor,

396.50.text:
>>>CRISTINA PASTOR: My
relatives, my friends are

397.93.text:
telling me you know it's so
safe to walk the streets now.

401.84.text:
We really like what he's doing.
So when I ask them what

406.17.text:
about the killings are you OK
with that. And they're not

409.81.text:
comfortable with the
killings, they still feel

411.95.text:
that the law, all this
cleaning up, that this

416.35.text:
campaign should operate
within the law, that there

419.62.text:
should be a hearing, there
should be a court, people

425.46.text:
>>>PAUL LIN: Acting with
impunity is something

427.09.text:
you'd expect from a
dictatorship like that of former

432.07.text:
martial law and bilked the
Philippine economy of

434.93.text:
billions of dollars coinciding
with the torture and murder

438.17.text:
of thousands. Today
some say President Duterte is

441.98.text:
getting things done,
fast tracking the resolution of

444.78.text:
problems like drugs
and crime. But in such an

448.18.text:
environment local officials
suspected of crimes still

451.72.text:
can get gunned down
even when they're turning

454.19.text:
themselves in. Politicians
critical of policies may find

458.02.text:
themselves on the
receiving end of smear tactics.

461.53.text:
Freedom of speech
and the press may suffer.

464.20.text:
>>>LUIS FRANCIA: People
are afraid, they don't

467.37.text:
want necessarily to come
out and say things that

471.20.text:
might be interpreted by
somebody in the

474.41.text:
neighborhood who might
want to score points or

478.41.text:
has a grudge and then
provides misinformation to

482.58.text:
the local cops. You never
know. So there's a lot of fear.

487.82.text:
>>>PAUL LIN: And what
about the Trump administration

489.49.text:
sometime in the near future
fast tracking a Chinese

492.39.text:
Exclusion Act for Muslims or
even going back to Japanese

504.07.text:
be used as parallels, you
know there is absolutely

508.88.text:
this fear that you will be
labeled a terrorist simply

514.81.text:
because of your faith.
Just as being a Japanese

519.55.text:
or Japanese America during
World War Two was enough

522.79.text:
too, for people to think
your civil liberties

527.49.text:
>>>PAUL LIN: All this from a guy
seen as a political outsider,

530.30.text:
someone supporters
believe may get things done

533.07.text:
in Washington. Fixing
everything wrong for those

538.44.text:
for failing to improve
their lives. In short a

541.34.text:
populist leader. And
across the world it's

544.11.text:
become a wave. We saw it
in the UK with the Brexit

547.45.text:
referendum but it's
elsewhere in Europe and

550.58.text:
it's definitely in the
U.S. and the Philippines.

553.65.text:
>>>CRISTINA PASTOR: Some
people are saying maybe

554.99.text:
the millennials are driving
this wave. I do not know.

558.29.text:
I don't know. Maybe also
it's a sense of despair that

566.40.text:
we have been in this
situation for a long time,

569.07.text:
at least in the Philippines
and nothing ever gets done.

571.57.text:
>>>PAUL LIN: One thing
scheduled to get done in

572.97.text:
2017 a White House visit
by the Philippine president

576.71.text:
invited by Donald Trump in a
recent telephone conversation

580.48.text:
and President Duterte
has reciprocated with

585.29.text:
I'm Paul Lin for
Asian-American Life.

589.69.text:
>>>KYUNG YOON: Asian-Americans
are the fastest growing ethnic

592.29.text:
group in the U.S
and according to the

594.53.text:
Pew Research Center nearly
half identify as Christians.

599.33.text:
The roots of Christianity in
Asian American communities

602.67.text:
date back to over a century
ago. It starts with the

608.98.text:
>>>EUGENE CHO: I think for
first generation they went

611.41.text:
to church yes because of faith,
part of it was for survival.

615.52.text:
It was where
they could go and rest.

624.02.text:
>>>KYUNG YOON: Eugene Cho
a Korean-American pastor

626.56.text:
in Seattle, Washington
leads a multi-ethnic and

630.00.text:
multicultural church
called Quest. He was six

634.03.text:
years old when his family
immigrated to the U.S. and

637.07.text:
has vivid memories of his
parents struggling to

642.74.text:
>>>EUGENE CHO: My parents
worked at a grocery store

646.15.text:
8 a.m. to 11 p.m. forcing
themselves to speak a

650.88.text:
language that they could
not speak. So when they

653.35.text:
went to church on Sundays
I saw them effervescent.

659.36.text:
>>>KYUNG YOON: He also saw
how the Church founded by

661.66.text:
Korean immigrants was more
than a spiritual home but

665.13.text:
also a place that provided
vital social services.

669.30.text:
>>>EUGENE CHO: So when
you're an immigrant,

670.94.text:
when you're a refugee, when you
are a marginalized outsider

676.68.text:
in a country where you're
a minority I think it makes

680.45.text:
our dependence on
faith, on Christ, that much

685.12.text:
more important, we don't
take it for granted.

687.52.text:
>>>DALE IRVIN: When people
immigrate they often have

689.22.text:
a hard time finding a
place to call home and

692.26.text:
churches have provided
that. The church's form

695.40.text:
culturally, they often
preserve the culture in America.

700.03.text:
>>>KYUNG YOON: President
Dale Irvin of the New York

702.44.text:
Theological Seminary says
that Asian-American churches

705.81.text:
today like all immigrant
churches are being challenged

709.68.text:
to balance the needs of new
generations of

712.35.text:
churchgoers who are culturally
assimilated and embracing

716.05.text:
new ideas about identity,
community and fellowship.

721.12.text:
>>>DALE IRWIN: So
I'm watching that happen

722.46.text:
inside the church, there's an
older generation of leadership

726.56.text:
and they have a certain
kind of understanding of

728.53.text:
what the church is like and
there is another generation

731.53.text:
coming up underneath them
that have a very different

733.73.text:
understanding of what
leadership is, a very different

737.10.text:
understanding of the kinds
of patterns that the church

747.81.text:
>>>DALE IRVIN: I still see
among Asian Americans a

750.52.text:
real sensitivity to the global
multicultural identity and not

755.42.text:
an exclusion, not trying to
outpace other groups but

758.63.text:
really trying to build a
new kind of community.

761.06.text:
>>>KYUNG YOON: The kind of
community that Pastor

762.83.text:
Eugene Cho says he felt
called to create in his church.

767.27.text:
>>>EUGENE CHO: As someone
living in the United States

770.54.text:
what I saw was an incredibly
fast changing culture.

774.61.text:
And while we needed
Korean-American and other

778.08.text:
homogenous churches
I believe God brought me

781.65.text:
to the United States, yes
to embrace my calling as a

785.52.text:
Korean-American person but
I also felt that part of

789.26.text:
my calling here was to be
a light and salt to the

793.09.text:
larger culture as well. If
church becomes reduced in

796.93.text:
the modern era where you
just come and go.

799.83.text:
>>>KYUNG YOON: Pastor Cho
is one of the growing

801.90.text:
numbers of visible
Asian-Americans in the

804.44.text:
Christian leadership. He's
met with President Obama

808.07.text:
and been invited by Martin
Luther King Jr.'s daughter

811.21.text:
Dr. Bernice King to speak
at the Ebenezer Baptist

815.15.text:
Church on Martin Luther
King Day. In recent years

819.25.text:
more and more
Asian-Americans are seen

822.39.text:
in prominent roles of
leadership. Intervarsity

825.49.text:
Christian Fellowship, one
of the largest evangelical

828.33.text:
organizations on college
campuses elected Tom Lin

832.27.text:
as the first nonwhite president
in its 75-year history.

837.07.text:
Lausanne Movement an evangelical
organization founded

840.17.text:
by world renowned
evangelist Billy Graham has as

843.91.text:
its CEO a Korean-American,
Michael Oh.

847.18.text:
And in 2016 the oldest Baptist
missionary organization

852.12.text:
in North America unanimously
elected Sharon Koh to

856.29.text:
be its executive director.
Koh is the first woman to

860.33.text:
lead the organization and its
more than 200-year history.

865.10.text:
>>>SHARON KOH: My favorite
parts about my face is

868.63.text:
that written on it is the
truth that God's mission

872.51.text:
is now from everywhere to
everyone. Because this

877.88.text:
gospel went all the way
and came all the way back

886.19.text:
>>>EUGENE CHO: We have
been at work on the ground,

889.46.text:
faithful, serving in churches,
serving in organizations for

892.96.text:
a long, long time. So I'm really
grateful and encouraged by that,

896.90.text:
I'm excited that other people
are beginning to recognize

899.90.text:
this as well. One
of my mentors his name

904.00.text:
is Dr. John Perkins is an
African-American activist who

908.71.text:
was part of the Civil
Rights Movement, spent time with

911.51.text:
Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.
He said everyone needs to be

917.45.text:
loved, everyone needs to
be heard and everyone

923.02.text:
needs to be part of something
greater than themselves.

926.69.text:
So as a church we want to
be able to speak of those

929.20.text:
things and certainly because
we have many Asian-Americans

932.90.text:
come to be culturally
sensitive to them as well.

936.54.text:
>>>KYUNG YOON: According
to the Pew Research Center

938.84.text:
immigrants are playing a
key role in revitalizing

942.31.text:
churches across America.
And it's clear that

945.75.text:
Asian-Americans are
helping to change the face

948.82.text:
of Christianity as leaders
and as laypeople.

952.89.text:
I'm Kyung Yoon for
Asian-American Life.

957.62.text:
>>>MINNIE ROH: I’m Minnie Roh,
it is a true Cinderella story,

960.73.text:
Korean-American author
Patricia Park spent 10 years

963.93.text:
working on her first novel
which finally got published

966.83.text:
in May 2015. And then Hollywood
came knocking on her

971.07.text:
door and now this book
is being adapted into a

974.14.text:
television series. The New York
Times calls it a truly fresh

979.31.text:
modern take on the coming
of age novel.

982.38.text:
Entertainment Weekly says
it's snappy and memorable.

985.99.text:
Still others have heralded
her writing style as astute,

993.23.text:
leaving the Main Street
Flushing Station-

995.70.text:
>>>MINNIE ROH: Re Jane is
a modern day spin on

998.00.text:
Charlotte Bronte classic
Jane Eyre. It's set in

1001.50.text:
Flushing, Queens and Jane
is a half Korean half

1005.00.text:
American orphan. The novel
begins with Jane finding

1008.57.text:
out that her Wall Street
job offer has disappeared

1011.51.text:
along with the dot com
bubble burst. She is

1014.58.text:
working at her family grocery
store under the watchful

1017.95.text:
eye of her disapproving
uncle. Where people judge

1020.95.text:
her because of her Hanyu
or mixed race heritage.

1024.79.text:
>>>PATRICIA PARK: Jane is like
a minority within a minority.

1027.56.text:
The girl kind of can't catch
a break and she has the

1029.83.text:
eyes a Flushing kind of looking
and parsing her genetics.

1035.80.text:
Patricia Park grew up in
Flushing. Her parents own a

1039.31.text:
grocery store and she admits she
sometimes felt out of place

1043.51.text:
dealing with the strict and
unspoken expectations of

1046.95.text:
life in a Korean home. How
much of Jane is actually you?

1052.79.text:
>>>PATRICIA PARK: Like Jane I
think I had a lot of these kind

1054.59.text:
of cultural eye opening
experiences where being in my

1059.26.text:
case born and raised in America
and being educated by an

1062.36.text:
American system you have one
way of thinking but then at

1065.00.text:
home it's a completely
different way.

1067.33.text:
>>>MINNIE ROH: As a young girl
Park says she was a loner,

1070.17.text:
always feeling like an
outsider. She sought refuge in

1075.94.text:
>>>PATRICIA PARK: Maybe it
was because I was one of

1077.68.text:
those chubby four eyed, brace
faced kids that spent recess

1082.32.text:
just reading books and not, I
didn't have a lot of friends.

1086.65.text:
>>>MINNIE ROH: Commuting
from Queens to the Bronx

1088.69.text:
during high school she
would pass by Manhattan

1091.16.text:
and find herself yearning to
one day head for the big city.

1094.76.text:
It was only through her
writing that she began to

1097.96.text:
embrace who she was, where
she came from and only then

1102.37.text:
was she able to appreciate
the beauty of her home borough.

1106.24.text:
>>>PATRICIA PARK: There
were so many rich stories

1107.67.text:
here despite the grit, despite
the blue collarness of the

1111.28.text:
borough and I want to show that
and I want to show how

1116.08.text:
something that seems so plain
and so just functionary

1121.25.text:
>>>MINNIE ROH: The beauty
in the story of Jane's journey

1123.59.text:
from outer borough
to inner peace caught the eye of

1127.26.text:
a well-known Korean star in
Hollywood, Daniel Dae Kim.

1131.50.text:
>>>PATRICIA PARK: Re Jane
is currently in development

1133.40.text:
for a TV series with
Paramount and TV Land

1137.70.text:
and Daniel Dae Kim
who we all famously know

1139.81.text:
for Lost and Hawaii Five-O
has his own production

1143.21.text:
company and his, and that
company took interest in my,

1147.05.text:
in my novel and they
wanted to get more

1153.15.text:
>>>MINNIE ROH: Park says
she never dreamed that she

1155.45.text:
would hit a homerun with her
first novel right off the bat.

1159.13.text:
What was it like
when you first heard that

1161.96.text:
he was going to executive
produce your book?

1164.26.text:
>>>PATRICIA PARK: I said
shut up, I'm like no, get out,

1168.10.text:
I may have like dropped the
phone and ran away.

1170.17.text:
I think actually I
was trembling. I'm like

1173.57.text:
and you know when
something good happens you

1174.94.text:
don't let yourself believe
it. And I still don't let

1178.08.text:
myself believe it because
there are still many obstacles.

1180.45.text:
From my understanding
Hollywood is like the field

1182.95.text:
of broken dreams or so
I- but ultimately I was so

1189.16.text:
floored and flattered and that
Jane's story resonated with

1195.90.text:
>>>MINNIE ROH: Margaret
Cho's All-American Girl in

1198.80.text:
the mid 90s featured a
Korean-American lead character.

1203.00.text:
The show was cancelled after
one season amid criticism for

1207.17.text:
watering down the material to
appeal to a wider audience.

1211.91.text:
As a consulting producer
Park vows that Re Jane will stay

1219.22.text:
>>>PATRICIA PARK: The writer
and I are continually in contact

1222.56.text:
you know almost on
a daily basis, she'll ask

1224.56.text:
questions about to get
those specific details

1226.76.text:
right like what are the names
of you know those middle aged

1230.43.text:
women with the curly perms
oh the ajumma then

1233.13.text:
I'll have to, then I'll go on a
whole cultural rant or lecture

1236.67.text:
about the role of the ajumma
in Korean society and

1241.04.text:
then that leads to
other questions.

1244.41.text:
>>>MINNIE ROH: The past decade
has been full of struggles

1246.71.text:
for Park but she never gave
up on her dream to publish

1250.28.text:
Re Jane. She took on several

1254.72.text:
at SUNY Purchase, publishing

1258.22.text:
filling in as needed at her
parents grocery store.

1262.09.text:
>>>PATRICIA PARK: There
were certain moments in

1263.83.text:
that basically decade long
process where you hit some

1267.00.text:
lows and you just, you don't
think you're going to climb

1269.40.text:
out of whatever hole or well
that you're in and you think

1272.37.text:
that the work will never
see the light of day.

1275.91.text:
>>>MINNIE ROH: But she

1278.24.text:

1281.75.text:

1293.59.text:

1296.73.text:

1301.03.text:
all of their struggles from

1303.74.text:

1307.37.text:

hopefully it's come to

1310.54.text:

1330.70.text:

1334.13.text:

Right there, that’s me.

1342.68.text:

that face every night.

1348.31.text:

1358.16.text:

1360.96.text:

1364.50.text:
on Broadway in 2014. For

1369.13.text:

When Disney called it was,

1375.11.text:

1378.58.text:

1382.72.text:

1386.59.text:

1389.59.text:
week like it's so

1423.92.text:

1427.03.text: I identified so much with her.

1433.20.text:

1455.59.text:

And speaking

1511.64.text:
I have to ask about that

1520.09.text:
>>>COURTNEY REED: Oh yeah,
well we have different

1522.62.text:

1524.49.text:

1534.07.text:

1537.44.text:

1542.31.text:

of the Opera. And Ann Sanders

1545.94.text:
is the first Asian-American
to play Anna in the

1548.61.text:

1552.75.text:

different doors have opened.
